background: Maternal stress and depression during pregnancy and infancy are associated with adverse child health outcomes and altered DNA methylation, but the biological mechanisms are unclear.
hypotheses: Prenatal stress and depression are associated with differences in newborn cord blood mononuclear cell DNA methylation (CBMC-DNAm).
Postnatal stress and depression are associated with differences in 12-month-old child peripheral blood mononuclear cell DNA methylation (PBMC-DNAm).
The cumulative effect of prenatal and postnatal adversity influences infant DNA methylation.
major_findings: Prenatal stress was significantly associated with differential CBMC-DNAm at 8 CpG sites, and prenatal depression at 2 CpG sites.
Postnatal stress was significantly associated with differential PBMC-DNAm at 8 CpG sites, and postnatal depression at 11 CpG sites.
Composite prenatal and postnatal adversity scores were associated with differential DNA methylation at multiple CpG sites, suggesting a cumulative effect of maternal mental health on infant DNAm.
null_findings: After adjusting for inflation and unmeasured confounding, many of the initial associations between maternal stress/depression and infant DNA methylation were no longer significant.
Functional enrichment analysis did not reveal any significantly enriched biological pathways associated with the differentially methylated CpG sites.
new_open_questions: What are the specific biological mechanisms by which maternal stress and depression influence infant DNA methylation?
Do the identified differentially methylated CpG sites have functional consequences for child development and health?
How do the cumulative effects of prenatal and postnatal adversity on DNA methylation contribute to long-term health outcomes?
